Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1438425

This project examines the mechanical properties of liquid interfaces that are coated by small particles. When the number of particles on a liquid interface is large, the particles can form arrangements called mesostructures, which can change the mechanical stiffness, permeability, appearance, or other properties of the interface. The project will use a combination of experiments, theory, and numerical calculations to show how mesostructure formation affects mechanical properties of the interface. Interfaces covered with particles appear in a wide variety of technological and biological applications including microcapsule formulations for food products and drug delivery, separations in mining operations, and improved, low-toxicity dispersants for treating oil contamination in bodies of water. The information obtained in this project will provide new methods for scientists and engineers to predict, analyze, and control the mechanical properties of interfaces, which can lead to innovative and mechanically robust products. This project will also support the training of undergraduate and graduate students for careers in science or engineering, and it will support outreach to K-12 students and teachers.

Particle-coated interfaces, called particle sheets, will be fabricated and their stiffness (moduli) for stretching and bending will be measured. Particle sheets will be subjected to stress or geometric distortion to identify three distinct responses, wrinkling or buckling, tearing or cracking, and the formation of particle-packing defects such as disclinations or dislocations. The response of a particle sheet to uniaxial compression will provide the bending modulus. The response to point-like forces imposed on the sheet by poking will provide the stretching modulus. Changing the curvature of a particle sheet by confining it on a curved interface will elucidate the competition among wrinkles, cracks and particle-packing defects. The experimental and theoretical activities in this project will lead to the development of a structural relaxation phase diagram for thin sheets composed of particles.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid interfaces that are coated by a layer of adsorbed particles occur widely in foods, insect colonies, particle separation technologies, oil-spill cleanup, and suppression of water evaporation in reservoirs. In solid-particle-stabilized (Pickering) emulsions, solid particles adsorb onto the interface between the two phases and thereby prevent droplet coalescence; they find application in crude oil recovery and targeted drug delivery. Similarly, particles can stabilize liquid-air interfaces, allowing the long-term stability of foams. In many of these examples, the mechanical response of the particle layer plays a crucial role in the applications.

This project examined interfaces covered with particles to develop new fundamental insights and new methods for scientists and engineers to predict, analyze, and control the mechanical properties of interfaces. Through a combination of experiments and theory, we studied the mechanical properties of liquid interfaces that are coated by assemblies of particles. In our experiments, we constructed layers of small particles (?rafts?) at air-water, oil-water and other fluid interfaces and then measured their response to forces applied with indenters of various shapes. We found that, surprisingly, throughout all of our measurements the rafts where equally stiff or even less stiff than the fluid interface by itself, despite the fact that the individual particles are very rigid.  By imaging the displacements of the particles and by comparing measurements to theory, we proposed a general explanation of the raft softness. We also showed how the response can change if the raft is compressed from its edges. Despite their low stiffness, rafts can withstand a deeper indentation than a clean fluid interface and thus a greater peak force. In many cases, we found that defects in the arrangement of particles (cracks in the raft) appeared at a particular distance from the indentation, a finding that remains to be explained by theory.

A general theoretical principle, called the Gauss-Euler elastica, was found to characterize the deformations of thin sheets that are forced to change their shape by indentation or confinement (e.g. between two curved surfaces). The theory was developed for uniform sheets and complements the studies of particle-based sheets or rafts. The Gauss-Euler elastica principle enables a great simplification in addressing theoretically the mathematically challenging nonlinear equations that characterize a broad class of slender-body problems.

The results obtained in this project will provide new methods for scientists and engineers to predict, analyze, and control the mechanical properties of particle- or sheet-coated interfaces in technological and biological applications. Examples include microcapsule formulations for food products and drug delivery, separations in mining operations, and improved, low-toxicity dispersants for treating oil contamination in bodies of water.

The project provided training for future scientists and engineers at many levels. The grant supported graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, who worked with the PIs and were trained with research and communication skills. The PIs also organized annual week-long training programs for graduate students, one-day science meetings for scientists and non-scientists at all levels, and an outreach program to all of the 8th-grade students ? more than 200 per year ? at the nearby regional middle school. The activities allow students to share the excitement of science. They contribute to developing the next generation of scientists and engineers for academia, industry, and other settings important to the national welfare.
